post.summary:
For performance reasons, it is recommended to keep this RPC
alive for the entire life of the application.

bounds.description: The values must be strictly increasing and > 0.

BucketOptionsExplicit.description:
[0, bucket_bounds[i]) for i == 0
[bucket_bounds[i-1], bucket_bounds[i]) for 0 < i < N-1
[bucket_bounds[i], +infinity) for i == N-1
BucketOptionsExplicit.title:
Specifies a set of buckets with arbitrary upper-bounds.
This defines size(bounds) + 1 (= N) buckets. The boundaries for bucket
index i are:

count.description:
The number of values in each bucket of the histogram, as described in
bucket_bounds.

exemplar.description: If the distribution does not have a histogram, then omit this field.

DistributionValueBucketOptions.description:
A Distribution may optionally contain a histogram of the values in the
population. The bucket boundaries for that histogram are described by
BucketOptions.

If bucket_options has no type, then there is no histogram associated with
the Distribution.

value.description:
Value of the exemplar point. It determines which bucket the exemplar
belongs to.

timestamp.description: The observation (sampling) time of the above value.

attachments.description: Contextual information about the example value.

DistributionValueExemplar.description:
Exemplars are example points that may be used to annotate aggregated
Distribution values. They are metadata that gives information about a
particular value added to a Distribution bucket.

MetricDescriptorType.description:
The kind of metric. It describes how the data is reported.

A gauge is an instantaneous measurement of a value.

A cumulative measurement is a value accumulated over a time interval. In
a time series, cumulative measurements should have the same start time,
increasing values and increasing end times, until an event resets the
cumulative value to zero and sets a new start time for the following
points.

 - UNSPECIFIED: Do not use this default value.
 - GAUGE_INT64: Integer gauge. The value can go both up and down.
 - GAUGE_DOUBLE: Floating point gauge. The value can go both up and down.
 - GAUGE_DISTRIBUTION: Distribution gauge measurement. The count and sum can go both up and
down. Recorded values are always >= 0.
Used in scenarios like a snapshot of time the current items in a queue
have spent there.
 - CUMULATIVE_INT64: Integer cumulative measurement. The value cannot decrease, if resets
then the start_time should also be reset.
 - CUMULATIVE_DOUBLE: Floating point cumulative measurement. The value cannot decrease, if
resets then the start_time should also be reset. Recorded values are
always >= 0.
 - CUMULATIVE_DISTRIBUTION: Distribution cumulative measurement. The count and sum cannot decrease,
if resets then the start_time should also be reset.
 - SUMMARY: Some frameworks implemented Histograms as a summary of observations
(usually things like request durations and response sizes). While it
also provides a total count of observations and a sum of all observed
values, it calculates configurable percentiles over a sliding time
window. This is not recommended, since it cannot be aggregated.

percentile.description:
The percentile of a distribution. Must be in the interval
(0.0, 100.0].

value.description: The value at the given percentile of a distribution.

SnapshotValueAtPercentile.description: Represents the value at a given percentile of a distribution.

count.description:
The number of values in the snapshot. Optional since some systems don't
expose this.

sum.description:
The sum of values in the snapshot. Optional since some systems don't
expose this. If count is zero then this field must be zero or not set
(if not supported).

percentile_values.description:
A list of values at different percentiles of the distribution calculated
from the current snapshot. The percentiles must be strictly increasing.

SummaryValueSnapshot.description:
The values in this message can be reset at arbitrary unknown times, with
the requirement that all of them are reset at the same time.

count.description:
The number of values in the population. Must be non-negative. This value
must equal the sum of the values in bucket_counts if a histogram is
provided.

sum.description:
The sum of the values in the population. If count is zero then this field
must be zero.

sum_of_squared_deviation.description:
Sum[i=1..n]((x_i - mean)^2)

Knuth, "The Art of Computer Programming", Vol. 2, page 323, 3rd edition
describes Welford's method for accumulating this sum in one pass.

If count is zero then this field must be zero.
sum_of_squared_deviation.title:
The sum of squared deviations from the mean of the values in the
population. For values x_i this is:

bucket_options.description:
Don't change bucket boundaries within a TimeSeries if your backend doesn't
support this.
TODO(issue #152): consider not required to send bucket options for
optimization.

buckets.description:
If the distribution does not have a histogram, then omit this field.
If there is a histogram, then the sum of the values in the Bucket counts
must equal the value in the count field of the distribution.

v1DistributionValue.description:
Distribution contains summary statistics for a population of values. It
optionally contains a histogram representing the distribution of those
values across a set of buckets.

node.description:
This is required only in the first message on the stream or if the
previous sent ExportMetricsServiceRequest message has a different Node (e.g.
when the same RPC is used to send Metrics from multiple Applications).

metrics.description: A list of metrics that belong to the last received Node.

resource.description:
The resource for the metrics in this message that do not have an explicit
resource set.
If unset, the most recently set resource in the RPC stream applies. It is
valid to never be set within a stream, e.g. when no resource info is known
at all or when all sent metrics have an explicit resource set.

description.description: A human-readable description of what this label key represents.

v1LabelKey.description: Defines a label key associated with a metric descriptor.

has_value.description:
If false the value field is ignored and considered not set.
This is used to differentiate a missing label from an empty string.

exporter_version.description: Version of Agent exporter of Library.

metric_descriptor.description:
The descriptor of the Metric.
TODO(issue #152): consider only sending the name of descriptor for
optimization.

timeseries.description:
One or more timeseries for a single metric, where each timeseries has
one or more points.

resource.description:
The resource for the metric. If unset, it may be set to a default value
provided for a sequence of messages in an RPC stream.

v1Metric.description: Defines a Metric which has one or more timeseries.

name.description: The metric type, including its DNS name prefix. It must be unique.

description.description: A detailed description of the metric, which can be used in documentation.

unit.description:
The unit in which the metric value is reported. Follows the format
described by http://unitsofmeasure.org/ucum.html.

label_keys.description: The label keys associated with the metric descriptor.

v1MetricDescriptor.description: Defines a metric type and its schema.

identifier.description: Identifier that uniquely identifies a process within a VM/container.

library_info.description: Information on the OpenCensus Library that initiates the stream.

v1Node.title:
Identifier metadata of the Node that produces the span or tracing data.
Note, this is not the metadata about the Node or service that is described by associated spans.
In the future we plan to extend the identifier proto definition to support
additional information (e.g cloud id, etc.)

timestamp.description:
The moment when this point was recorded. Inclusive.
If not specified, the timestamp will be decided by the backend.

summary_value.description: A summary value. This is not recommended, since it cannot be aggregated.

host_name.description:
The host name. Usually refers to the machine/container name.
For example: os.Hostname() in Go, socket.gethostname() in Python.

start_timestamp.description: Start time of this ProcessIdentifier. Represented in epoch time.

v1ProcessIdentifier.description: Identifier that uniquely identifies a process within a VM/container.

labels.description: Set of labels that describe the resource.

count.description:
The total number of recorded values since start_time. Optional since
some systems don't expose this.

sum.description:
The total sum of recorded values since start_time. Optional since some
systems don't expose this. If count is zero then this field must be zero.
This field must be unset if the sum is not available.

snapshot.description: Values calculated over an arbitrary time window.

v1SummaryValue.description: The start_timestamp only applies to the count and sum in the SummaryValue.

start_timestamp.description:
Must be present for cumulative metrics. The time when the cumulative value
was reset to zero. Exclusive. The cumulative value is over the time interval
(start_timestamp, timestamp]. If not specified, the backend can use the
previous recorded value.

label_values.description:
The set of label values that uniquely identify this timeseries. Applies to
all points. The order of label values must match that of label keys in the
metric descriptor.

points.description:
The data points of this timeseries. Point.value type MUST match the
MetricDescriptor.type.

v1TimeSeries.description:
A collection of data points that describes the time-varying values
of a metric.
